abstractText: We propose a method to engineer repulsive long-range interactions between ultracold ground-state molecules using optical fields, thus preventing short-range collisional losses. It maps the microwave coupling recently used for collisional shielding onto a two-photon transition and takes advantage of optical control techniques. In contrast to one-photon optical shielding [Xie et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 125, 153202 (2020)], this scheme avoids heating of the molecular gas due to photon scattering. The proposed protocol, exemplified for Na K, should be applicable to a large class of polar diatomic molecules.

sections.text:
PHYSICAL REVIEW RESEARCH 5, 033074 (2023)
Two-photon optical shielding of collisions between ultracold polar molecules
Charbel Karam , Romain Vexiau , Nadia Bouloufa-Maafa, and Olivier Dulieu Université Paris-Saclay, CNRS, Laboratoire Aimé Cotton, Orsay 91400, France
Maxence Lepers Laboratoire Interdisciplinaire Carnot de Bourgogne, CNRS, Univ. Bourgogne Franche-Comté, F-21078 Dijon, France
Mara Meyer zum Alten Borgloh , Silke Ospelkaus, and Leon Karpa Institut für Quantenoptik, Leibniz Universität Hannover, 30167 Hannover, Germany
(Received 7 November 2022; accepted 7 June 2023; published 3 August 2023)
We propose a method to engineer repulsive long-range interactions between ultracold ground-state molecules using optical fields, thus preventing short-range collisional losses. It maps the microwave coupling recently used for collisional shielding onto a two-photon transition and takes advantage of optical control techniques. In contrast to one-photon optical shielding [Xie et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 125, 153202 (2020)], this scheme avoids heating of the molecular gas due to photon scattering. The proposed protocol, exemplified for 23Na 39K, should be applicable to a large class of polar diatomic molecules.
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevResearch.5.033074
I. INTRODUCTION
The full understanding and modeling of few-body systems remains a long-standing challenge in several areas of science, like, for instance, in quantum physics. The possibility to create and manipulate dilute gases at ultracold temperatures, composed of particles with kinetic energies E = kBT 1 mK, opened novel opportunities in this respect. The growing availability of quantum gases of ultracold polar molecules (i.e., possessing a permanent electric dipole moment in their own frame) in several labs revealed a very peculiar situation in the context of few-body physics: At ultracold energies, two such molecules in their absolute ground level (i.e., in the lowest rovibrational and hyperfine level of their electronic ground state) collide with a universal collisional rate, even if they have no inelastic or reactive energetically allowed channels, so they leave the molecular trap with a short characteristic time. Such a four-body system, which may look rather simple at first glance, is not yet fully characterized. It is currently interpreted as a “sticky” four-body complex [1,2], with a huge density of states, for which various statistical models have been developed [3–5]. However, the experimental observations reported up to now regarding the molecular loss rates [6–9] cannot yet be consistently reproduced by these models [10–13].
Instead of attempting to fully describe this four-body system, with the aim of identifying the exact cause of the universal loss rate, one can design protocols where molecules
Published by the American Physical Society under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license. Further distribution of this work must maintain attribution to the author(s) and the published article’s title, journal citation, and DOI.
would simply not reach short distances in the course of their collision. Several options have been proposed and experimentally demonstrated, based on the modification of the long-range interaction (LRI) between molecules using static electric fields [14–18] or microwave (mw) fields [19–23] to shield their collisions. In a previous paper [24], we proposed an alternative way to engineer LRIs using a laser with a frequency blue-detuned from the one of a suitable molecular rovibronic transition. Such a one-photon optical shielding (1-OS), inspired from previous works on cold atoms [25,26], results in the laser-induced coupling of the attractive collisional entrance channel to a repulsive one, thus preventing the molecules from reaching short distances and from creating a sticky complex. One limitation of the 1-OS could be the heating of the molecular quantum gas due to the continuous scattering of off-resonant photons of the 1-OS laser.
In this paper, we propose a two-photon optical shielding (2-OS) scheme, aiming at overcoming the above limitation, while mapping the case of the mw shielding (Fig. 1). As described below, such a scheme combines the best features of the 1-OS (no restriction for the field polarization, convenient laser power, tunability, geometrical versatility, broad compatibility) and mw shielding (no spontaneous emission or photon scattering). The scheme relies on coupling three molecular states |g1〉, |q〉, and |g2〉 of the collisional complex, with R-dependent energies [i.e., the longrange potential energy curves (PECs) of Fig. 1(a)] via a two-photon transition from |g1〉 to |g2〉 occurring preferentially at the intermolecular distance R = RC [Fig. 1(b)]. In the dressed state picture [Fig. 2(a)], this maps the mw shielding scheme [20,21] onto an effective optical coupling of the states |g̃1〉 and |g̃2〉 (i.e., the dressed states).
2643-1564/2023/5(3)/033074(9) 033074-1 Published by the American Physical Society

By convention, we define red detuning as (R), δ(R) > 0. The R dependence of the detunings originates from the R-dependent dipole-dipole interaction (DDI) between the molecules, determining their long-range PECs. Additionally, as R varies, the state composition also varies as shown later in Appendix 3, which results in an R dependency of the Rabi frequency. In the following, we thus define 1= 1(R → ∞), 2= 2(R → ∞), = (R → ∞) and δ=δ(R → ∞).

sections.heading: B. Adiabatic elimination
sections.text:
When (R) is much larger than 1(R) and 2(R), and the radiative decay rate q of |q〉, H̃ I (R) can be reduced, by adiabatic elimination of the |q̃〉 state [28], to the matrix HIeff (R) of an effective two-level system expressed in the (|g̃1〉, |g̃2〉) basis,
HIeff (R) = h̄ (
0 − eff (R)/2 − eff (R)/2 eff (R) ) |g̃1〉,|g̃2〉 , (5)
where
eff (R) = 1(R) 2(R) 2 (R) , (6)
and
eff (R) = δ(R) + 2 1(R) − 22(R)
4 (R) . (7)
This scheme is equivalent to the mw shielding (Fig. 2), with an important difference: The initial and final states have the same total parity, so the channels relevant for 2-OS will be different from those of the mw shielding. Nonetheless, the same requirement still holds: Identifying a channel with a repulsive PEC which could be coupled to the entrance channel via a two-photon transition. Moreover, it is worth noting that there is no intrinsic limitation on the magnitude of eff , which could be taken arbitrarily large, as long as it does not reach another energy level.
If we now set δ(R) = 0 at a given distance, the Raman resonance is achieved so one of the eigenvectors of the Hamiltonian in Eq. (4) is a dark state, | dark〉 = [ 2(R)|g̃1〉 − 1(R)|g̃2〉]/
√ 21(R) + 22(R), ensuring that the excited state|q〉 is not populated at this distance, thus exactly canceling spontaneous emission and photon scattering. Two options can be considered:
(i) δ = 0 for R → ∞: The individual molecules are then protected against photon scattering, so the ultracold molecular
sample in the trap will not be heated while applying the 2-OS scheme [Fig. 2(a)].
(ii) δ(RC ) = 0: The molecular pair is less protected against photon scattering while the 2-OS is indeed active at the crossing point between the PECs of the two dressed channels.
At ultracold temperatures, the molecules spend most of their time at very large distances. As argued in Ref. [24], the shielding dynamics proceeds with a characteristic time shorter than the radiative lifetime of a suitable |q〉 state. Therefore, option (i) is preferable in most experimental realizations. We thus assume δ = 0, while the variation of the detunings (R), δ(R), and eff (R) for the realistic case described below are detailed in Appendix 2. To ensure a crossing between |g̃1〉 and |g̃2〉 and that the population distribution of the dark state at R → ∞ is predominantly in |g1〉, which is the case for 2 > 1, we chose > 0 and eff < 0.

sections.heading: C. Basis set and selection rules
sections.text:
In the presence of an external field, the molecular states |g1〉, |g2〉, and |q〉 of the pair of identical molecules are appropriately described in the SF frame, and expanded over the basis set of symmetrized vectors |[ξi, ji, pi, ξk, jk, pk], jik, , J, M〉, where ξi, ji, pi (respectively, ξk , jk , pk) are the quantum numbers for the electronic state, the rotational state, and the parity of molecule 1 (respectively, molecule 2). The angular momenta ji and jk are first coupled to yield jik with the quantum number jik , which is then coupled to the relative angular momentum (thus the partial wave ) to build up the total angular momentum J with quantum number J and projection M on the field polarization axis (z axis of the SF frame). We assume that the molecules occupy the lowest vibrational level vi = vk = 0 of their electronic state, and this label will be omitted in the rest of the paper.
The potential energy operator includes the dominant DDI, which couples basis vectors satisfying ξi ≡ ξ ′i , | ji| ≡ | ji − j′i | = 1, pi p′i = −1, ξk ≡ ξ ′k , | jk| ≡ | jk − j′k| = 1, pk p′k =−1, and | | ≡ | − ′| = 0, 2 [29]. All higher order multipolar interactions are neglected. The diagonalization of this operator yields the PECs schematized in Fig. 1(a) associated with the eigenvectors |g1〉, |g2〉, and |q〉, and detailed in Sec. III A. When the shielding lasers are present, they impose selection rules for the one-photon transitions |g1〉 → |q〉, |q〉 → |g2〉, resulting from those on the basis vectors themselves, and depending on the laser polarization. At large distances, the Coriolis effect is small, leaving unaffected by the lasers. We assume that the collision energy is small enough to proceed in the s-wave regime ( = 0). The selection rules are
(1) Circular polarization (σ ): = 0, J = 0,±1, M = +1 (σ+), or M = −1 (σ−), and for the quantum numbers of the individual molecules, ξα = ξ ′α , | jα| = 1, pα p′α = −1, applying for α = i or k, but not both simultaneously.
(2) Linear polarization (π ): = 0, J = ±1, M = 0, and for the quantum numbers of the individual molecules, ξα = ξ ′α , | jα| = 1, pα p′α = −1, applying for α = i or k, but not both simultaneously.
033074-3

sections.heading: III. APPLICATION TO BOSONIC NaK
sections.text: We apply this proposal to 23Na 39K bosonic molecules in the lowest vX = 0, jX = 0 rovibrational level of their electronic ground state X 1 + (noted X for short afterward).The molecular hyperfine structure is small [30] and not considered here. In general, the experiments are performed in the presence of an external magnetic field imposed by the location of a Feshbach resonance used to create the groundstate molecules. According to the Supplemental Material of Ref. [20], the magnetic field above which the hyperfine structure could be neglected is generally small enough for most alkali-metal diatomic species, opening the possibility to choose a suitable Feshbach resonance. We formulate the 2-OS by relying on the lowest excited electronic state of 23Na 39K (the b3 0 state, noted b afterward), as in Ref. [24]: The bottom of the b PEC lies below all PECs dissociating to the first excited dissociation limit Na(3s)+K(4p), so the two-photon transition could be implemented with a detuning from the lowest vibrational level vb = 0. The b state is weakly coupled to the excited A1 + state via spin-orbit interaction (referred to as the A/b system afterward), yielding a pair of electronic states with = 0+ symmetry, being the projection of the total electronic angular momentum on the 23Na 39K molecular axis. The transition X ↔ (A/b) is thus dipole-allowed through the A component of the lowest 0+ state of the A/b system, resulting in a transition electric dipole moment (TEDM) of 0.0456 a.u. (or 0.116 Debye) [24] for the vX = 0 ↔ vb = 0 transition.

sections.heading: A. Long-range potential energy curves
sections.text:
The long-range potential energy curves (LR-PECs) are calculated in the SF frame following the same procedure as in Refs. [24,31]. They include the dominant DDI at first order of perturbation, while the second-order van der Waals terms vary as R−6, which result from the presence of the electronically excited states inducing an additional instantaneous small dipole to the system are neglected. We use the same parameters as those reported in Ref. [24] NaK: The permanent electric dipole moments d0X = 1.095 a.u. and d0b = 1.220 a.u, and the rotational constants B0X = 0.0950 cm−1 and B0b = 0.0951 cm−1 for the X 1 +(vX = 0) and b3 0(vb = 0) levels, respectively, the TEDM between these two levels d0X↔b = 0.0456 a.u. (all quantities in the body-fixed frame, and with 1 a.u. = 2.541 580 59 Debye).
Due to the bosonic character of 23Na 39K, only even partial waves = 0, 2 are considered when the two molecules are in the vX = 0, jX = 0 state, i.e., in the entrance channel with J = 0, 2. We include in our calculations for two ground-state molecules colliding with jX and j′X even partial waves up to = 8 to describe states with ji, jk = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, with total angular momentum up to J = 0, 1, 2. This yields 22, 33, and 61 basis vectors |ξi, ji, pi, ξk, jk, pk, jik, , J, M〉 for J = 0, 1, 2, respectively. As is conserved in our approach, and because the DDI couples states satisfying = 0, 2, we consider the same range of variation for the quantum numbers when a ground-state molecule in a |X, vX = 0, jX 〉 state collides with another one in a |b, v0+ = 0, jb〉 state. The size of the basis set is now 119 and 190, for J = 1 and J = 2, respectively.
The LR-PECs for two molecules in vX = 0, or one molecule in vX = 0 interacting with another one in vb = 0, are displayed in Figs. 3 and 4, respectively. We note in Fig. 4 the quasi-degeneracy of the two limits X ( jX = 1) + b ( jb = 0) and X ( jX = 0) + b ( jb = 1) resulting from the almost equal rotational constant of the vX = 0 and vb = 0 levels. This induces a strong mixing between the states correlated to these asymptotes. This pattern is actually present in all heteronuclear alkali-metal diatomic molecules [24]. Note that the lowest dissociation limit jX = 0 + jb = 0 is not appropriate for our 2-OS scheme as it possesses only a J = 0, 2 manifold of states and thus would not be coupled by light to the entrance channel.

sections.heading: B. Mapping the MW-S
sections.text:
To map the mw shielding scheme, we build the 2-OS scheme by choosing the |g2〉 state among the molecular pair states correlated to [ jX = 0 + jX = 2](+), which exhibits several repulsive LR-PECs (the A’, B’, and C’ curves in Fig. 5). The components of these adiabatic states associated with the
033074-4
three repulsive LR-PECs A’, B’, C’ (for J = 2), are reported in Table III of Appendix 3, expressed on a basis set limited to 15 vectors. Note that these curves vary as C6/R6 with so-called “giant” C6 coefficients, with magnitude of about −106 a.u. for the A’ curve, and a few −105 a.u. for the B’ curve (see, for instance, Refs. [29,32,33]). In the entrance channel we calculated the LR-PECs for J = 0, 2. The J = 2 curve is entirely determined by the centrifugal barrier = 2 with a height of about kB × 63.26 µK, much higher than the typical collision energy in ongoing cold molecule experiments (Ecol/kB of a few hundreds of nK). We thus only considered the channel J = 0 as |g1〉, composed of a single basis vector. To comply with the selection rules, the |q〉 state is taken from the set of adiabatic states correlated to the [ jX = 0 + jb = 1](−) and [ jX = 1 + jb = 0](−) quasidegenerate dissociation limits. The adiabatic states, and the related PECs, are obtained from the diagonalization of the DDI in the basis sets above for every in-
termolecular (large) distance R. The coupling of the adiabatic states by the OS lasers is determined by the nonzero matrix elements of the X ↔ b TEDM between basis vectors fulfilling the selection rules. After eliminating the intermediate |q〉 state, the 2-OS scheme results in a crossing point RC between an attractive entrance PEC and a repulsive rotationally excited one, corresponding to a given value of the effective detuning eff .
We illustrate the selected LR-PECs for the 2-OS of collisions between two ground-state 23Na 39K molecules in Fig. 5(a). Assuming an adiabatic connection of |g1〉, |g2〉 and |q〉 to their dissociation limit, the 2-photon transition can be labeled as |g1〉[ jX = 0 + jX = 0](+) → |q〉[ jX = 0 + jb = 1](−) → |g2〉[ jX = 0 + jX = 2](+). After investigating the composition of all the adiabatic states on the above basis set and by taking into account the selection rules, we can characterize an efficient scheme with a pair of σ polarized photons connecting the appropriate components (listed in Table I for eff = −70 MHz) of |g1〉 to those of the I and K excited states, and in turn to those of the A’, B’, and C’ repulsive states [Fig. 5(a)]. In Appendix 3, we display a similar table for other values of eff (or RC values), showing that the variation in
TABLE I. The components (in %) of the |g1〉, |g2〉, and |q〉 adiabatic states which fulfill the selection rules for the two-photon transition in σ polarization at RC ≈ 240 a.u., assuming eff = −70 MHz.
State |[ξi, ji, pi, ξk, jk, pk], jik, , J, M〉 Component (%) |g1〉 |[X, 0, 1, X, 0, 1], 0, 0, 0, 0〉 99.95 |q〉(I) |[X, 0, 1, b, 1, −1], 1, 0, 1, 1〉 33.06 |q〉(K) |[X, 0, 1, b, 1, −1], 1, 0, 1, 1〉 16.74 |g2〉(A’) |[X, 0, 1, X, 2, 1], 2, 0, 2, 0〉 10.90 |g2〉(B’) |[X, 0, 1, X, 2, 1], 2, 0, 2, 0〉 9.89 |g2〉(C’) |[X, 0, 1, X, 2, 1], 2, 0, 2, 0〉 78.88

R of the composition of the adiabatic states is weak enough to keep the same character at all distances larger than RC . Equivalently, a pair of π polarized photons can be used as it also fulfills the selection rules, with the appropriate change of angular factors.
By Figs. 5(a) and 5(b), we realize that our 2-OS scheme nicely maps onto the one-mw-photon shielding approach proposed in Refs. [20,21] based on the mw transition jX = 0 → jX = 1, and observed experimentally with 23Na 40K molecules with mw = −2π × 8 MHz and mw = 2π × 11 MHz [19]. Choosing here the same values for eff and eff , the Rabi frequencies 1 and 2 can be evaluated (see Fig. 6) for different values of and δ as 2 = 2 eff/ 1 and
1 = √ 2 √ ( eff − δ) + √ ( eff − δ)2 + 2eff . (8)

sections.heading: IV. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION
sections.text:
The working principle of 2-OS and its mapping onto MWS is best explained by the cleanest coupling of the (weakly dipole-allowed) X -b transition: The b state is the lowest electronic state accessible via a dipole-allowed transition, leading to the most isolated, or closest to the idealized three-level scheme. Considering the weak TEDM of the quasiforbidden one-photon transition vX = 0 → vb(0+ ) = 0, the range of 1 and 2 values varying with (with δ = 0) displayed in Fig. 6 leads to quite large laser intensities. However, as the Raman condition δ = 0 is fulfilled at infinity (i.e., for
individual molecules), one can significantly reduce the value of without hampering the efficiency of the 2-OS scheme. Moreover, as the proposed scheme can be generalized to any intermediate state |q̃〉, excited electronic states with large TEDM can be readily used, allowing for moderate laser intensities I1 and I2. For example, coupling via the A1 + state in 23Na 39K yields the desired eff/(2π ) ∼ 10 MHz with an estimated I2 ( I1) on the order of 104 W/cm2 for 1/ 2 ∼ 10−2, and a loss probability due to off-resonant scattering below 10−6 per collision. Note that the two-photon coupling scheme allows using a common laser source in combination with frequency modulation for driving both optical transitions. Thus, the optical phase noise is the common mode and the overall phase stability is determined by the purity of the mw modulation source. Therefore, we expect that the proposed scheme could be successfully implemented in a forthcoming experiment, helped by full dynamical calculations extending those of Ref. [24] to the 2-OS case.
In summary, we have proposed a scheme for shielding of inelastic and reactive short-range collisions based on twophoton transitions. It allows taking advantage of optically driven transitions including insensitivity to polarization and flexibility in the choice of electronic states, while suppressing undesired off-resonant photon scattering which was present in the previously proposed 1-OS. Our method is applicable to a broad range of bialkali molecules, with expected efficiencies comparable to the previously demonstrated mw shielding scheme. Our results may be of importance in experiments where collisional losses, in general, pose a major limitation to the achievable lifetimes and densities of ultracold molecular gases.
033074-6

sections.heading: 1. Variation of the Rabi frequencies for the 2-OS
sections.text:
In Fig. 7, we present a generalization of Fig. 6, showing the variation of the individual Rabi frequencies (a) 1 and (b) 2 as functions of and δ, for fixed values of eff and eff . We see that the variation with δ is smooth, so the experimental

realization of the 2-OS could consider some flexibility on δ, with a possible compromise between the 2-OS efficiency versus the full cancellation of the photon scattering rate.

sections.heading: 2. Variation of the detunings characterizing the 2-OS
sections.text: In Sec. II A, we exposed the reasons for the dependence of the detunings , δ, and eff on the intermolecular distance R, i.e., as the collision between the molecules develops. These variations are displayed in Fig. 8 when the Raman condition δ = 0 is fulfilled at infinity, thus for individual molecules [case (i) in Sec. II B]. We see that the R variation of the PEC of the |q〉 states, and thus of (R), does not affect the behavior of the 2-OS: Namely, the variations of eff and δ remain weak for R > RC , and the magnitude of dominates the process for all distances. In other words, the conditions for adiabatic elimination remain fulfilled at all relevant distances.

sections.heading: 3. Variation of the adiabatic states composition for the 2-OS
sections.text:
In Table II, we report, for several crossing distances RC , or effective detunings eff , the largest components of the I and
TABLE IV. The components (in %) of the I and K adiabatic states, evaluated for eff = −500 MHz or RC = 167.9 a.u. The numbers in boldface correspond to the components on the vectors which are allowed by the selection rules. Note that the states connected to [ jX = 0 + jb = 1](−) are strongly mixed to [ jX = 1 + jb = 0](−) by the DDI.
Basis vector |[ξi, ji, pi, ξk, jk, pk], jik, 〉 Component J = 1, M = 1 I K |[X, 0, 1, b, 1, −1], 1, 0〉 33.16% 16.68% |[X, 0, 1, b, 1, −1], 1, 2〉 16.35% 32.92% |[X, 1, −1, b, 0, 1], 1, 0〉 33.49% 16.76% |[X, 1, −1, b, 0, 1], 1, 2〉 16.55% 33.08% |[X, 1, −1, b, 2, 1], 1, 0〉 <0.01% <0.01% |[X, 1, −1, b, 2, 1], 1, 2〉 <0.01% <0.01% |[X, 1, −1, b, 2, 1], 2, 2〉 0.06% <0.01% |[X, 1, −1, b, 2, 1], 3, 2〉 0.09% 0.11% |[X, 1, −1, b, 2, 1], 3, 4〉 0.06% 0.15% |[X, 2, 1, b, 1, −1], 1, 0〉 <0.01% <0.01% |[X, 2, 1, b, 1, −1], 1, 2〉 <0.01% <0.01% |[X, 2, 1, 1, −1], 2, 2〉 0.06% <0.01% |[X, 2, 1, b, 1, −1], 3, 2〉 0.1% 0.11% |[X, 2, 1, b, 1, −1], 3, 4〉 0.07% 0.15%
033074-7
K excited states that can be coupled to the entrance channel, and the largest components of the A’, B’, and C’ states that can be coupled to those I and K components. We see that the variation of the composition of the adiabatic states is smooth over a broad range of distances, yielding flexibility to the choice of laser frequencies and intensities which, for a constant target shielding efficiency ( eff/2π = 11 MHz and
eff/2π = −8 MHz), allows balancing between an optimal suppression of residual off-resonant scattering and a favorable composition of the dark state (that is, minimizing the [X ( jX = 0) + X ( jX = 2)](+) component).
We also present in Tables III and IV the full composition of the adiabatic states at a Condon point RC = 167.9 a.u. corresponding to an effective detuning of eff = −500 MHz.

title: Two-photon optical shielding of collisions between ultracold polar molecules
